uncivil: numbers cannot be mapped to a double datatype using match_mapping_type.  That part probably needs clarification though I'm not sure how to do it. Basically, the json parser assumes the wider datatype that is not a BigDecimal/BigInteger. So floating-point numbers will be detected as a `double` rather than a `float` and integers will be detected as a `long` rather than an `integer`. You can dynamically map floating-point numbers to doubles by using `double` as a `match_mapping_type` and `double` as a type i
civil 1 -1 0: [It seems that mapping numbers to a double datatype using match_mapping_type is not supported. This part could use some clarification, although I'm unsure of the best approach. Essentially, the JSON parser assumes a wider datatype, such as BigDecimal/BigInteger. As a result, floating-point numbers are detected as double rather than float, and integers are detected as long rather than integer. To dynamically map floating-point numbers to doubles, you can use double as the match_mapping_type and double as the type.] 	1 -1 0

uncivil: If you are using the Java API you are considered to be a full blown part of the cluster. Since major version require full-cluster restarts you have to restart the client as well. We all know that this sucks and we are working on a real java client since today we don't have one. The java client is really an elasticsaerch node (lightweight) even if you use the transport "client". What others have build is a custom REST interface tailored to their domain such that they can talk to different version of the cl
civil 1 -1 0: [If you're using the Java API, you're considered an integral part of the cluster. Since major versions require full-cluster restarts, the client also needs to be restarted. We acknowledge that this is inconvenient, and we're actively working on developing a dedicated Java client. It's important to note that the current Java client is essentially a lightweight Elasticsearch node, even when using the transport "client". Other solutions you may have come across are custom REST interfaces tailored to specific domains, allowing communication with different versions of the cluster.] 	1 -2 -1

uncivil: I'll review it. This should be a huge win.  Today we don't support `doc['field']`, leaving only `doc["field"]` and `doc.field`. We document/recommend `doc.field` only because double quote escaping such as `doc[\"field\"]` is hellacious. But `doc.field` is much slower.  Being able to support `doc['field']` gives us consistency with the script engines today, and it gives a 50% performance increase (we gave it more type information, removes dynamic lookup).
civil 1 -1 0: [I'll review it. This change should bring significant benefits. Currently, we don't support `doc['field']`, which leaves us with only `doc["field"]` and `doc.field`. We recommend using `doc.field` due to the challenges of double quote escaping like `doc[\"field\"]`. However, accessing fields with dot notation (`doc.field`) is slower. By introducing support for `doc['field']`, we achieve consistency with the existing script engines and gain a 50% performance increase by providing more type information and eliminating dynamic lookups.] 	4 -1 1

uncivil: This is an issue tracker, not a help center.  Next time you should really ask for help in the IRC channel or the forum.  I'm not trying to be a dick, I'll help you out since this is a simple question, but just keep this in mind.  You only need to dispose a `Shape` if you (or some third-party library) created it in Java code (i.e. with `new CircleShape()` or something).  If you call `fixture.getShape()`, you do NOT need to `dispose()` the resulting `Shape`; in fact, don't do so, you'll crash your game.  `S
civil 1 -1 0: [This platform primarily serves as an issue tracker rather than a dedicated help center. For future reference, it's recommended to seek assistance in the appropriate channels such as the IRC channel or forum. However, I understand your need for a quick resolution, so let me provide the necessary guidance. In this case, you only need to dispose of a Shape if it was created in Java code using 'new CircleShape()' or a similar approach. If you obtain the Shape through 'fixture.getShape()', there is no need to call 'dispose()' on it. Doing so could potentially lead to a game crash.] 	1 -1 0

uncivil: @user First, thanks for trying to get K-9 Mail to work with PGP/MIME encrypted/signed messages!  However, I don't think this is the right approach. This pull request doesn't address the core problem that prevents us from having proper PGP/MIME support. It's the fact that K-9 Mail doesn't store messages in a way that allows reconstructing byte-identical copies of the original message. Worse, we can't even retrieve the structure of the original MIME tree. This pull request contains a lot of very nasty hacks
civil 1 -1 0: [@user, I appreciate your efforts to make K-9 Mail compatible with PGP/MIME encrypted/signed messages. However, I don't believe this pull request addresses the fundamental issue preventing proper PGP/MIME support. The problem lies in how K-9 Mail stores messages, making it impossible to reconstruct byte-identical copies of the original message or retrieve the structure of the MIME tree. This pull request includes several hacks that may not be sustainable in the long run.] 	2 -4 -1

uncivil: @user I don't think using `final String topic = topicName;` is a good idea. IIRC sink can use multiple input topics (via `--inputs`) and we'd want to route them to appropriate destinations. "_" appear as result of replacement of ":" and "/" in the full topic name (URI as in "persistent://tenant/ns/topic") that snowflake connector does internally to generate table name compatible with the snowflake. Theoretically, topic2table mapping of `"persistent___tenant_ns_topic:cooltablename"` might work though it di
civil 1 -1 0: [@user, I have reservations about using 'final String topic = topicName;' in this case. If I recall correctly, the sink can handle multiple input topics through '--inputs' and we need to ensure they are routed to the correct destinations. The '_' characters are a result of replacing ':' and '/' in the full topic name (URI format like 'persistent://tenant/ns/topic') for compatibility with the Snowflake connector's table naming convention. Theoretically, a topic-to-table mapping like 'persistent___tenant_ns_topic:cooltablename' might work, but it's worth considering the implications.] 	2 -1 1

uncivil: As stated a several times, its the nature of the beast. And so many different factors can contribute to the lower response on TechEmpowered. Add to this servers tend to run FB-DIMM what is different beast then your Unbuffered-Dimms.   Hell, maybe your CPU is using SSL

uncivil: y did the "every operator has to ensure it is closed" thing. It was a complex mess. (We didn't have `Sequence` to help.) Then Drill let it's fragment runner do the work. The code became much simpler and resource leaks disappeared, even in nasty error situations.  The operator prototype learned from Drill's experience. The operator "DAG" is managed by a fragment runner which knows of every operator in the DAG, and which ensures that, come hell or high water, the operators are closed. The result is that the
civil 1 -1 0: [The previous approach of ensuring every operator is closed was quite complex and messy. However, with the introduction of the fragment runner in Drill, the code became simpler and resource leaks were eliminated, even in error situations. The operator prototype in Drill learned from this experience. The fragment runner manages the operator DAG and guarantees proper closure of operators. As a result, the code is more robust and reliable.] 	1 -3 -1

uncivil: I think I found the **root cause**: the **libtool crap in freeswitch** (again). configure finds libopusenc and declares the related defs. however, when mod_opusfile.c gets compiled, they are simply not used. And therefore the [write file part](https://github.com/signalwire/freeswitch/blob/master/src/mod/formats/mod_opusfile/mod_opusfile.c#L222) of it gets skipped and a generic error returned, without giving any log message about the reason =8-( . It finally gets linked against libopusenc, but that's obvio
civil 1 -1 0: [I believe I've identified the root cause: the libtool issue in freeswitch (once again). During configuration, libopusenc is detected, and the related definitions are declared. However, when mod_opusfile.c is compiled, those definitions are inexplicably unused. As a result, the write file part of the process is skipped, and a generic error is returned without providing any log message to indicate the reason. It eventually gets linked against libopusenc, but that's obviously not sufficient.] 	1 -3 -1

uncivil: > it sucks that we need to implement grow-ability to save cost of zeroing out where we already have allocated all the memory or is there any other advantage?.  The problem is the memory is not initialized when we allocated it, so it has garbage in it, and therefore we need to initialize the parts we're going to use. And initialization can take a while if your buffer size is big (like a gigabyte, as some people do).  > Instead, if we reserved numBucket bytes at the start of buffer and used those for markin
civil 1 -1 0: [It's unfortunate that we need to implement grow-ability to avoid the cost of zeroing out already allocated memory. Is there any other advantage to it? The issue is that the memory is not initialized when allocated, so it contains garbage values. Consequently, we must initialize the portions we intend to use. However, initialization can be time-consuming for large buffer sizes (e.g., a gigabyte, as some users may have). Perhaps reserving numBucket bytes at the start of the buffer for marking purposes could be a viable alternative.] 	1 -2 -1

Finalize will be slower, but it is very infrequent.   - The problem is OOMs because of inability to reclaim finalizable objects on a given GC phase. Allocating larger objects only makes it worse.  - Currently StupidPool of ByteBuffers allocates as many ByteBuffers as ResourceHolders, the effect of changing that resource
civil 1 -1 0: [@user, I noticed that ByteBuffer.allocate() is used 152 times, allocateDirect() is used 6 times, and Files.map() is used 9 times. Additionally, we already have a finalize in Memory as a fallback in case someone forgets to free explicitly. While finalize may be slower, it is infrequently triggered. The problem we're facing is OutOfMemory errors due to the inability to reclaim finalizable objects in a given GC phase. Allocating larger objects only exacerbates the issue. Currently, the StupidPool of ByteBuffers allocates as many ByteBuffers as ResourceHolders. Changing that behavior could have an impact on resource management.] 	1 -3 -1

uncivil: `--define` is more than just `goog.define`s. You can also have non-Closure `@define`s (like `COMPILED` in base.js). A bundle won't replace these and it doesn't make sense for them to go in `CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES`. I think it would be confusing if `--define` always set the Closure defines as a result.  There are work arounds, obviously. You can pass an input to the compiler that sets `CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES` and it will 1) output that to the bundle and 2) respect that in a compile. Then it is
civil 1 -1 0: The usage of --define extends beyond goog.defines. It also includes non-Closure @defines, such as COMPILED in base.js. In this context, using a bundle to replace these defines and always setting the Closure defines through --define could lead to confusion. However, there are workarounds available. For example, you can provide an input to the compiler that sets CLOSURE_[UNCOMPILED_]DEFINES. This approach ensures that the defines are properly outputted in the bundle and respected during compilation. 	2 -2 -1

uncivil: @user You need to add `.toWebElement()`:  ```java actions().moveToElement($(".gsfi").toWebElement()).perform(); ```  The point is that `$(".gsfi")` is not a "real" `WebElement`, but a proxy object (created by Selenide). If you call "usual" methods on this proxy objects, everything works.  But actions builder doesn't call "usual" methods, but uses black magic (which fails with the proxy object).  Namely, actions builder calls `BeanToJsonConverter` which uses reflection and iterates all _properties_ of give
civil 1 -1 0: [@user, to resolve the issue, you need to add .toWebElement() as follows:```javaactions().moveToElement($(".gsfi").toWebElement()).perform();```The reason is that $(".gsfi") is not a direct WebElement but a proxy object created by Selenide. While regular methods work on this proxy object, the actions builder relies on different mechanisms, causing it to fail with the proxy object. Specifically, the actions builder invokes BeanToJsonConverter, which uses reflection and iterates over the properties of the given object.] 	1 -1 0

uncivil: @user I think we might already be at peak-workaround. The webrtc folks, in their infinite wisdom, do not seem to think it's important to support "ringing." As soon as I build a PeerConnection, it tries to take over and play an AudioTrack w/ STREAM_VOICE_CALL whether the AudioTrack is enabled or not.  If I try to play sounds with MODE_RINGTONE, they'll just get hijacked by webrtc and end up in the earpiece.  The only thing I can do is play the ringtone into the voice call stream, but turn the speaker on.
civil 1 -1 0: [I believe we might have exhausted all possible workarounds. It seems that the webrtc team, for some reason, does not consider supporting "ringing" as important. When a PeerConnection is established, it automatically takes over and plays an AudioTrack with STREAM_VOICE_CALL, regardless of whether the AudioTrack is enabled or not. Consequently, any attempts to play sounds with MODE_RINGTONE are intercepted by webrtc and end up in the earpiece. The only option left is to play the ringtone into the voice call stream while keeping the speaker on.] 	1 -1 0

uncivil: This is what causes problem with date values:  ``` Unrecognized type 'java.sql.Date' - can't convert to numeric ```  DBeaver thinks that this column has numeric data type. This is because you second column has the same alias as the real table column (date_key). DBeaver tries to discover real attribute data type from database metadata whenever it is possible. Smarty pants.  Workaround - set some alias for your expression. And I'll think how to handle this problem better..
civil 1 -1 0: [This is the issue causing problems with date values:```Unrecognized type 'java.sql.Date' - can't convert to numeric```DBeaver mistakenly identifies this column as having a numeric data type. The confusion arises because the second column shares the same alias as the actual table column (date_key). DBeaver attempts to determine the real attribute data type from the database metadata whenever possible. A workaround is to assign a different alias to your expression. I will also explore better ways to handle this problem.] 	2 -2 -1

uncivil: The test ran close to midnight. In SQL, when casting `TIME` to any other temporal type, the current date is added. The engine gets the current date at some point in time, and the test creates the expected value at some other time. When these two happen at a different day, the test fails...  To fix we need to assert that the actual value is this or the next day, an ugly generalization...
civil 1 -1 0: [The test ran close to midnight, and in SQL, when casting TIME to any other temporal type, the current date is added. The engine retrieves the current date at a specific point in time, while the test creates the expected value at a different time. When these two occur on different days, the test fails. To resolve this, we need to assert that the actual value is either on the current day or the next day, which is an unfortunate generalization.] 	1 -3 -1

uncivil: ilt-in modules like `bazel_tools` and `local_config_platform` because your MODULE.bazel file is empty), `@platforms` actually refers to `@@platforms~0.0.5`. This is important because when we search for an appropriate execution platform (most likely your host machine), `@local_config_platform//:host` actually uses the platforms defined in `@@platforms~0.0.5`, but `rules_nodejs` defines toolchains for platforms defined in `@@platforms`.  The immediate workaround would be to add a single line in your MODULE.
civil 1 -1 0: [When using built-in modules like 'bazel_tools' and 'local_config_platform' (even if your MODULE.bazel file is empty), it's important to note that '@platforms' actually refers to '@@platforms~0.0.5'. This distinction is crucial because when searching for the appropriate execution platform (typically your host machine), '@local_config_platform//:host' utilizes the platforms defined in '@@platforms~0.0.5', while 'rules_nodejs' defines toolchains for platforms defined in '@@platforms'. As a temporary workaround, you can add a single line to your MODULE file.] 	1 -1 0

civil 1 -1 0: [The line '2' took me a bit longer than expected, but I appreciate Kotlin's strictness. In Kotlin, '0' is of type 'Int,' while '0f' is of the correct type 'Float.' uncivil: `Future.sync()` can raise any type of throwable.  To be strict, its method signature should have `throws Exception`.  However, we chose not to, in favor of overall brevity in user code.  As you mentioned, it increases the verbosity of user code when a user attempts to catch a checked exception:  ``` try {     f.sync(); } catch (Exception e) {     if (e instanceof ConnectException) { ... } } ```  We find this ugly, but it isn't as ugly as having to try-catch for every `f.sync()` even if you don't really wa
civil 1 -1 0: The `Future.sync()` method has the potential to raise any type of throwable. Strictly speaking, its method signature should include `throws Exception`. However, we made a deliberate choice to prioritize brevity in user code. As you mentioned, this decision increases the verbosity when catching checked exceptions. While we acknowledge that it may not be the most elegant solution, it is still preferable to having to try-catch every `f.sync()` invocation, even when not explicitly required. 	1 -3 -1

civil 1 -1 0: [To perform the lengthy check and subsequent optional fix, the recommended method, implemented by kimchy, is to take the defect node down (using the shutdown API or kill), allow the ES cluster to readjust to the new situation, enable a "fix" check setting value explicitly in the defect node's index setting, and then start the node again. uncivil: Model snapshots and the `latest_record_time_stamp` field are emitted by the autodetect process, internally autodetect works at a second resolution and when it writes a model snapshot as JSON to be consumed by Elasticsearch it converts the seconds to milliseconds.   http  I'm labelling this as `won't fix` because converting autodetect to sub-second resolution is a large undertaking.
civil 1 -1 0: [The autodetect process emits model snapshots and the latest_record_time_stamp field internally. Autodetect operates at a second resolution and converts the seconds to milliseconds when writing a model snapshot as JSON for Elasticsearch. Converting autodetect to sub-second resolution would be a significant effort, so I'm labeling this as won't fix.] 	1 -1 0

civil 1 -1 0: [@user, there's nothing wrong with your English proficiency as far as I can tell.
